user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskExit:
```c
void OS_TaskExit()
{
    osal_id_t         task_id;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    task_id = OS_TaskGetId_Impl();
    if (OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_TaskDetach_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(OS_SUCCESS, &token);
    }

    /* call the implementation */
    OS_TaskExit_Impl();

    /* Impl function never returns */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_object_token_t         token;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: in the fragment `OS_object_token_t token;` token is an object instance, not a pointer type, so MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 (about pointers pointing to const-qualified types) does not apply. (If, alternatively, `OS_object_token_t` were actually a typedef for a pointer type — e.g. `typedef struct S *OS_object_token_t;` — then declaring `OS_object_token_t token;` would create a pointer-to-mutable and could violate Rule 8.13; in that case the pointer should point to a const-qualified type when modification of the pointee is not intended.)
